conclusion: Analyze how shadows A, B, C, and D would change when the light source moves to the back left above the objects.
The image shows a green floor surface with several objects on it.
The first image shows red arrows pointing to shadows labeled A, B, C, and D.
A is the shadow of what appears to be a white cloth or paper.
B is the shadow of a small tabletop mirror.
C is the shadow of a metal ring.
D is the shadow of what looks like an avocado.
The shadows are currently positioned to the right/front-right of their objects, suggesting the light source is currently positioned somewhere to the front-left of the scene.
When a light source moves, shadows move in the opposite direction.
If the light source moves to the back-left position, the shadows will move to the front-right.
The current light is coming from the front-left based on shadow positions.
The new light will come from the back-left, meaning the light is moving from front to back.
Shadow A currently extends to the right/front-right and will extend to the front-right when the light moves to the back-left.
Shadow A will move forward (toward the viewer) and may become shorter.
Shadow B currently extends to the right/front-right and will extend to the front-right when the light moves to the back-left.
Shadow B will move forward (toward the viewer) and may become shorter.
Shadow C is a circular shape slightly offset from the ring and will extend to the front-right when the light moves to the back-left.
Shadow C will move forward (toward the viewer) and may become more elongated/oval.
Shadow D currently extends to the right/front-right and will extend to the front-right when the light moves to the back-left.
Shadow D will move forward (toward the viewer) and may become shorter.
All shadows will shift toward the front-right (opposite to light movement) when the light source moves to the back-left.
Shadows will likely become shorter if the light is moved higher.
